title: 110_hr392
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009 will have designs emblematic of the region, with flexibility in inscription placement. The 2009 quarter dollars will have designs representing the District of Columbia and territories, with inscriptions on the reverse and coin value on the obverse side. The 2009 quarter dollars will feature designs representing the District of Columbia and territories, with inscriptions on the reverse side and coin value on the obverse side. The design on the reverse side of each quarter dollar issued during 2009 will be emblematic of the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Each of the 6 designs required for quarter dollars shall be selected as per the subsection. The 2009 quarter dollars will feature designs representing the District of Columbia and territories, with inscriptions on the reverse side and coin value on the obverse side. Each of the 6 designs required for quarter dollars shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the chief executive of the District of Columbia or the territory being honored. The designs for the 2009 quarter dollars representing the District of Columbia and territories will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with designated officials and reviewed by the Commission of Fine Arts and Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Designs for quarter dollars may be submitted for selection and approval by the Secretary in accordance with the process developed at the Secretary's discretion. Participation by District or territorial officials may be included. The Secretary has developed a design selection and approval process for quarter dollar designs, with participation from District or territorial officials, artists, engravers, and the general public. The designs must be dignified and not frivolous. The Secretary must ensure that quarter dollar designs are dignified and not frivolous. No portraits of living or deceased individuals are allowed in the design. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars of selected designs in uncirculated and proof qualities, considered numismatic items under sections 5134 and 5136. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars of selected designs in uncirculated and proof qualities, with a 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper content. Timing and order of issuance are also determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will mint quarter dollars with 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper content to honor the District of Columbia and territories in 2009 in a specific order. The Secretary will mint quarter dollars with 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper content to honor the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the United States Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in a specific order. If the District of Columbia or any territory becomes a state before the end of a 10-year period, specific provisions will apply. Quarter dollars with designs emblematic of a territory will not be minted if the territory becomes independent or ceases to be a possession of the United States. The definition of territory is provided for this subsection. The subsection defines "territory" as specific regions under US possession, including Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, US Virgin Islands, and Northern Mariana Islands. If a territory becomes independent or no longer a US possession, quarter dollars with their designs will no longer be minted under this subsection. The House of Representatives passed the bill on January 23, 2007. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
